Princeton Ethiopic Manuscript No. 65: Miracles of Mary

physdesc.physfacet: Manuscript on parchment, mostly in gatherings of 10 leaves. The main body of the text is written in 2 columns of 15 lines, in black with the usual rubrics (opening lines of individual texts, the name of Mary, the original owner's names, partially erased, and major punctuation.), in a moderately large hand (7-9 mm in height) in a cursive gwelh or räqiq script. The leaves towards the end of the MS [fols. 105-150] are written in a somewhat larger gwelh hand [10-12mm] in 2 columns of 11 lines. Original pricking and ruling is visible throughout. There are 59 paintings, 52 of which are full-page and the others part or half-page, most of which are protected by muslin panels sewn on to the leaves. There is also a small detached painted leaf sewn to a blank leaf at the back of the MS [fol. 151]. All the paintings are executed in the Second Gondarene style. The MS is bound between wooden boards covered in tooled red-brown leather. Illumination: There are 59 full-page paintings illustrating 32 miracles, all painted in the classic court style that developed in Gondar during Dawit's reign. The style is initially dependent on European engravings but is here fully refashioned in a narrow range of figure types and brilliant colours. It can be closely compared with a painting in a manuscript of the Legends of Mary made for King Bäkaffa around 1721 and now in the British Library (British Library, Or. 603). The style of the paintings, which is a particularly fine example of the Second Gondarene period of painting, conforms with a date in the first half of the eighteenth century. This style with its heavily modelled features, rich colouring and solid backgrounds, is normally associated with the reign of Iyasu II [1730-55], though its roots must go further back to the earlier part of the century. The manuscript is discussed in C. Griffith Mann, Art of Ethiopia (London: Sam Fogg Rare Books, 2005), pp. 116-17. The Princeton University Library purchased it from Sam Fogg Rare Books, London, in 2012. Acc. 2012-71 Paintings: The style of the paintings belongs to the full Second or Late Gondarene style, which flourished from about 1730 onwards. Typical is the heavy modelling of the flesh and the folds of garments and draperies, the latter often with simple linear or dot decoration. Occasionally, richer patterning is shown, imitating brocade [see for example painting 29, fol. 52v]. The figures are all set against coloured backgrounds, which usually shade from green through yellow to red. Most of the pictures are also enclosed with a simple coloured frame, and sometimes elements of the picture extend into or outside the frame. A few paintings also show what look like uncoloured linear drawings of figures or architectural details that extend outside the frame. The palette is predominately dark red, vermilion, green, yellow, dark blue, purple and brown.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchase, 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Date and Provenance: Probably commissioned by the King Dawit III (reigned 1716-21). Though partially erased, the name Dawit appears throughout the text. The form of words does not include the formula "for our king," most often used though this is not always present in royal manuscripts. Dawit appears prostrate in one of the paintings wearing a luxurious Indian dress. Dawit's elder brother, who preceded him as king from 1706 to 1708 following the death of their father Iyasu I (Iyasu the Great) was Täklä Haymanot I and this name seems occasionally to accompany that of Dawit in the partially erased dedications.

As is usual, there is no colophon giving details of provenance. Each of the texts in the main body of the MS [fols. 3-100] closes with an invocation for blessings upon the owners. The names of the original owners, which were written in red, have been erased throughout, though at times somewhat imperfectly. The preceding text makes it clear that the original owner was a man, and the dedication also occasionally mentions a female as well, perhaps his wife or sister. The man's name is in several places recoverable as Dawit, though the space left for it in the black text is too large and the name is usually preceded or followed by decorative punctuation marks (säräz .).

In a few places there are traces of a second name, [Täklä] Haymanot accompanying that of Dawit. The woman's name is in places recoverable as Hadä[fä] Maryam, though elsewhere another name, Awdokseya (?), appears. The names inserted over these erasures are Arkälédes (m.) and Rébén (f.). The script is in keeping with a date during the first half of the eighteenth century, showing many gwelh-like features: large size, regularity of form, a tendency to a top-heavy structure with short letter heads (especially in ò, å), a pronounced hook in the vowel mark of ¶. The modern letter •Á appears in its older form which was still in use until the second half of the eighteenth century. The manuscript appears to have been in western Europe since the 19th century. On the back flyleaf pf the manuscript is a European dealer's or owner's ticket (handwritten on a blue printed label); the number appears to be in a German hand. The manuscript later passed through the hands of the dealer Merton D. Simpson, ca. 1970; the collector Alen Revier, 1971-1997; the dealer Milos Simovic, 1997-2004; and Sam Fogg Rare Books, London, 2004-2012.

Text: The principal text of the manuscript [fols. 7-99] is a collection of 32 miracles of the Virgin Mary. The basic canon of the Miracles, as described by Cerulli, comprised 32 miracles, but Ethiopian collections sometimes include others. The basic collection was subject to addition even before the translation of the Arabic Vorlage into Ethiopic in the fifteenth century, and some Ethiopian collections run to an enormous size. The largest collection known to date (BL Or. 643, dated 1717) contains no less than 316 miracles, though smaller collections are the more usual. Examples of the Ethiopian Miracles of Mary are to be found in all the major collections of Ethiopian manuscripts, such as the Biblioteca Vaticana, the British Library, the Bibliothèque Nationale, the Fonds Conti Rossini of the Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei, the Cambridge University Library, etc. The basic work dealing with the Ethiopian Book of the Miracles of Mary is Cerulli's Il libro etiopico dei Miracoli di Maria, Rome 1943; see also E.A. Wallis Budge, The Miracles of the Blessed Virgin Mary and the Life of Hanna, London 1900, and by the same author, Legends of Our Lady Mary, the Perpetual Virgin, and Her Mother Hannâ, London 1922, and One Hundred and Ten Miracles of Our Lady Mary, London, 1923.

In the present manuscript each Miracle is numbered. Miracle 29 is incorrectly numbered as 30, and those following are consequently incorrectly numbered. The miracles here follow the traditional sequence. Each miracle text closes with a brief hymn to the Virgin Mary. The Miracles are preceded by the short text [fols. 3r-6r].
The manuscript closes [fols. 100v-150v] with a collection of hymns or litanies to the Virgin Mary, including the Hymn of the Flower [Mahlétä S'egé].

did.unittitle: Introduction to the Miracles of Mary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Beginning, "The angels worship Mary from within the veil, and they say to her 'Hail to thee, Mary, restorer of the Lamb.'" The section concludes [fols. 5v-6r] with a hymn of salutation [sälam] to the Virgin Mary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Beginning, "In the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost. One God. A miracle of Our Lady, the Holy Twice Virgin, Mary, Mother of God."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of Hildefonsus of Toledo [Däqseyos of T'elt'elya in the Ethiopian version], followed by two short hymns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hildefonsus [Däqseyos] hands his book of the Miracles to the Virgin Mary. The text reads 'How Däqseyos wrote for her.'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin offers a throne and a robe to Dexius. The text reads 'How she gave him a throne and a robe'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An angel strikes down the bishop who stole Hildefonsus' throne. The text reads 'How he fell and died'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the craftsman who venerated the Virgin Mary constantly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The craftsman appears before the Virgin Mary. The text [incomplete] reads 'How she blessed this ...'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the Jew from Akhmim

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin raises up the Jew of Akhmim, who also appears fallen at her feet. The text reads 'How she raised him up.'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin blesses the Jew of Akhmim. The text reads 'How she made him stand at her right hand.'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the monk Damianus of Philippi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the left Damianus is shown writing the Virgin's name, whilst on the right she restores his sight.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of Pope Leon [Abbas of Romé in the Ethiopic] whose hand was restored after he had cut it off when a woman touched it as he was administering the Eucharist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the centre Leon touches the woman, whilst on the right he cuts off his hand. The text reads 'those who receive the body and blood of Our Lord'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin restores Leon's hand. The text reads 'How she gave him life'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of Isaac the monk who dedicated his prayers to the Virgin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin raises the fallen Isaac, as she had promised him in a dream. The text reads 'How he fell. How she raised him up'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the daughter of the man of Defra to whom the Virgin appeared from out of her icon and whom she promised to take directly to Paradise.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin leads the girl to Paradise. The text reads 'How she guided her'. The end of the hymn text following the miracle is included within the frame of the painting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the painter who fell while decorating a church and was restored by the Virgin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The painter falls from the scaffolding, but is caught by the Virgin. He is also shown at the top painting the blessed in heaven. The text reads 'How he fell. How she raised him up'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the sick pilgrim whom the Virgin transported to Jerusalem.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [half-page] The Virgin appears to the sick man, whose head and shoulders appear in a cloud at her feet. The text reads 'How she appeared to the sick merchant'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin and three figures stand above the recumbent figure of the merchant-pilgrim.The texts above the painting read 'It is Jerusalem' and 'How she brought him'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the young man Zacharias who crowned the head of a picture of the Virgin daily with roses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the left Zacharias crowns the Virgin's image with roses, whilst on the right he stands before the image. The text reads simply 'How he crowned her'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin and angels appear to Zacharias.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of Juliana and Barbara who were robbed of their bread whilst on pilgrimage to Jerusalem.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [half-page] The thieves rob Juliana and Barbara. the texts above the figures simply read 'the thieves' and 'the girls'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The now repentant thieves stand before the Virgin who appears from within her church. The text reads 'How those thieves became monks'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of three Arabs who were shipwrecked, two of whom were saved when they prayed to the Virgin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [three-quarter page]: On the left all three Arabs appear in the sea, whilst one is swallowed by the whale, whilst on the right the two Arabs who have been saved look on. The text simply reads 'the Arabs'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Arabs make their offerings at the church. The text describes the two gifts, 'some wool' and 'this camel'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the church of 'Eqona that was removed to the edge of the Mediterranean Sea [called Iyariko = Jericho) in the Ethiopian version].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin appears to the priest and his congregation in a dream.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The church and its congregation is transported to the sea shore. The text above simply gives the name of the church 'Eqona.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the blind priest, Yohannes Bäkänsi, whose sight was restored with milk from the breast of the Virgin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [three-quarter page] The blind priest stands before the image of the Virgin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin restores his sight with milk from her breast. The text reads 'Yohannes the old man whom she cured'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: the story of the rich man from Qwälasyes who was healed by the Virgin of an arrow wound in the eye, sustained whilst fighting the Turks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [half-page] The rich man and his companions in their boat. The texts read (in the top margin) 'the rich man of the island of Qwälasyes', and (just above the picture) 'the boat; the sail' [SIC].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The rich man is wounded in the ye, and (below) his image is healed by the Virgin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of Elisabeth, daughter of Abraham of Bäderman, whose sight was restored by the Virgin by sprinkling her eyes with milk from her breast.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Her mother brings the blind girl before the Virgin's image. The text in the top margin reads 'How she healed her'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin appears to the girl and restores her sight with milk from her breast. The incomplete text above the painting reads 'this is ...'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the poor widow, the marriage of whose daughters was arranged by the Virgin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The widow stands before the Virgin's image whilst her daughters are shown seated in the background. The text in the top margin reads 'How she relieved the old woman of her wretchedness'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The widow is buried whilst her daughters look on.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the two brother scribes, one of whom had been writing a copy of the Miracles of Mary and whose soul was rescued by the Virgin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The two scribes, described in the text as 'the two brothers'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin rescues the scribe's soul from devils.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of St. George the Younger whom the Virgin rescued from prison.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: St. George in prison on his iron griddle; the Virgin appears to him in the form here of a green dove. The text reads 'How she appeared to him'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the old priest called Kät'ir, whom the Virgin defended when he was banished from his church.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [half-page] The Virgin addresses the guardian of the church.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin blesses the old priest, whilst in the top left-hand corner the church guardian is shown expelling him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the dyer called Näzib who was rescued at the Virgin's behest by St. George from prison where he was falsely detained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the left, Näzib and his brother receive the pieces of cloth for dying; top-right, St. George attacks the judge who condemned Näzib falsely; bottom-right, he is shown in prison.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Näzib is acquitted and receives his pardon from the qadi.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the man with a club foot who was healed by the Virgin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the left, the man tells the bishop of his ailment, whilst on the right, he is cured of his club foot and gives thanks to the image of the Virgin. The text reads 'she cured the Frank ['afrengawi].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The man shows the bishop his healed foot.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of Bishop Mercurius whom the Virgin cured of leprosy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Top, the archbishop tells Mercurius he cannot serve as a priest whilst he has leprosy; bottom, Mercurius takes his leave of his congregation (?). The text at the top of the painting simply names Mercurius, who seems to be shown twice with his robe pulled off his shoulders to expose his leprosy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the right, Mercurius stands before the Virgin, who heals him, whilst on the left, he shows the archbishop that he is now cured.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: the story of the woman of Haarlem (Hartälrom in the text here) with a lame foot who was healed by the Virgin Mary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The woman is born on a litter by her relatives and placed before the image of the Virgin. The text reads 'the lame woman'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin cures the woman, who is then shown standing before the Virgin's image.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of Abbess Sophia who conceived a child, and whose reputation was saved by the Virgin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin supervises the delivery of Sophia's child by angels, who then hand the child to Felix [Filkes in the text here].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: the bishop addresses the nuns

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sophia tells her story to the bishop, and Felix [Filkes] verifies it, producing the child.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the rich and dissolute man, Barok of Finqi, who was saved by the Virgin Mary because of his devotion to her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Barok gives a banquet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A composite picture showing variously Barok being attacked by his enemies; Barok being nursed; Barok telling his sins to the priest; and the Virgin Mary who oversees all these events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the deacon Anastasius.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Anastasius stands before the Virgin's image, and (right) she appears to him in a dream in which she tells him he will join her in Paradise. The text simply identifies Anastasius [Anest'asyos].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the monk of the monastery of Abba Samu'el in Qälmon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The man is attacked by his fellow monks and seized by them. The text reads 'how they seized him'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The monk stands in prayer before the Virgin's image, having now lost his cap with which he miraculously made a breach in the wall to escape. The text reads 'how threw off the cap from his head'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the cannibal of Qemer whose soul was saved by the Virgin Mary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A composite picture showing the cannibal dismembering his relatives; giving water to a leper; the farmers who set out to catch him. the two brief texts simply identify 'the cannibal' and 'the farmers'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A composite picture showing Christ commanding the devil to surrender the cannibal's soul; St. Michael weighing the cannibal's soul in the balance; the Virgin Mary with Christ's blessing retrieving the cannibal's soul.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the widow's son who was a thief, whom the Virgin saved at his mother's request.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The thief steals from the Virgin's church.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Top, the thief's mother prays before the Virgin's image; bottom, the thief is rescued by St. Michael from his bonds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the woman who gave birth in a storm at sea with the Virgin's protection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [three-quarter page] The Virgin shields the woman and her child with her cloak, while the congregation look on from the shore. The text reads 'How she saved her'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The woman and her child amongst the congregation of her church. The text simply reads 'the faithful'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The story of the Virgin and the thirsty dog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin gives water to the dog from her slipper, whilst below, her companions attempt to drive the dog away from the water jars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virgin and Child with the archangels and below, the prostrate figure of the donor or commissioner of the manuscript.

did.unittitle: blank except for two lines of pen trials
A hymn to the Virgin Mary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Beginning, "O Virgin, call to mind before the Keeper of Records who forgets nothing, call to mind, o Virgin, for my sake the birth through you of Him who was born in Bethlehem ...' Followed by a hymn of salutation [sälam] to the Virgin."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: a collection of hymns or songs to the Virgin Mary known as the Hymn or Canticle of the Flower [Mahlétä S'egé], beginning, "A flower appeared, shooting forth from the bone of him who greeted thee, the flower of Gabriel…".

did.unittitle: blank leaf with a smaller [190 x 200mm] painted leaf sewn on

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: containing a painting of an equestrian saint attacking a centaur. Two equestrian saints, Claudius [Gälawdéwos] and Victor [Fiqt'or] are shown in Ethiopian tradition spearing a centaur. There is no text to identify which saint is portrayed here. The painting is in the Second Gondarene style and can be dated to the 18th century.

did.unittitle: Princeton Ethiopic Manuscript No. 66: Book of Magico-Medical, Divinatory and Astrological Texts

physdesc.physfacet: Parchment manuscript in gatherings of various sizes, most frequently of 8. The thickness of the parchment varies considerably, and almost all leaves show signs of heavy wear, staining and rubbing. Single column text, varying number of lines (between 16 and 35), written in a mixture of Ge'ez and Amharic, variously in black with some rubrics, also in red, and in purple in a number of different hands. There are 32 charts and talismanic drawings (25 full-page, 7 part-page) in ink, and in addition there are 4 bifolia of coloured paintings inserted loosely into the manuscript. Bound in a plain parchment cover and preserved in a skin double carrying case with strap.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No specific owner's name is identifiable throughout, though several prayers contain the name of a certain Gäbrä Mika'él Täsämma (sometimes just given as Gäbrä Täsämma). In addition, one of the loose bifolia contains a picture of a certain Ato Amarä Zäbehéral (? end of the second name unclear). The various hands, all of which are of poor quality, together with the paintings on the inserts, which show some western pigments, are indicative of a late 19th cent. date.

The text comprises a typîcal däbtära's manual of various magico-medical, divinatory and astrological texts together with sample talismanic drawings. Notable is the set of charts from the divinatory text, the Awdâ Nägäst, or Cycle of the Kings.
Purchase, 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In Amharic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In Amharic with some Ge'ez.

did.unittitle: Various spells for combatting demons, the evil eye, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: incorporating magical names, in Ge'ez except for one [fols. 14v-15v] which is in part at least in Arabic, or what purports to be Arabic, written in Ethiopian script.

did.unittitle: Prescription for curing typhoid or typhus

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In Amharic.

did.unittitle: Talismanic drawing in the form of an eight-pointed star with a central face
Various magical prayers for binding and destroying demons

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Placed within the text is a further talismanic drawing in the form of an eight-pointed star and a chart. The prayers also contain "magical" or talismanic letter-forms.

did.unittitle: Talismanic drawing to accompany "the prayer of Moses"
Talismanic drawing in the form of the cosmic serpent
Various magical prayers for the binding and destruction of demons, evil spirits, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Within the text are placed 4 talismanic drawings and charts.

did.unittitle: Sequence (in various hands) of prayers with talismanic drawings for summoning demons
Prayers, some unspecified, others for female ailments, incorporating lists of magical names [asmat]
Computations for predicting an individual's preferment or appointment to office [hasabä simät]
Astrological text concerning "the will of 7 stars and 12 stars' [mäfqedä 7 käwakebt wäzä-12 käwakebt]
"Calculation of hours [of daylight] and of darkness" [Sefrä sä'at wäs'elalot]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: For each of the months of the year, followed by a numerical chart given the hours of daylight and darkness for the month of Tahsas.

did.unittitle: 16 charts of the Awdä Nägäst [The Cycle of the Kings]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An Ethiopian text probably originally composed in the 15th cent., which by means of circular tables [awd] allows the diviner or fortune teller to find answers to specific questions posed by his clients. The 16 tables are each named after Ethiopian lakes or rivers.

did.unittitle: Prayer addressed to Jesus Christ seeking divine blessing and protection from and power over devils and spirits
[blank except for a single line of text]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In Amharic, with some Ge'ez.

did.unittitle: A series (30 chapters or sections) of prescriptions for casting the fortunes of men and women

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In Ge'ez, with some Amharic.

did.unittitle: "The Book of Precise Knowledge" [Mäs'hafä Temhert T'eyyuq]
A series of calculations [hasab] for divining various topics, such as success of a journey, birth of children, appointment to office, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly in Ge'ez but with occasional Amharic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unrelated to the text in which it is inserted.
Front: St. George and the dragon.
Interior: blank except for ball-pen scribbles.
Back: Holy Trinity with the four evangelical zoa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unrelated to the text in which it is inserted.
Front: Virgin and Child.
Interior left: crowned figure of Christ in the iconography of the Ecce Homo.
Interior right: Crucifixion.
Back: blank except for a rough drawing of a face and a pen trial.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unrelated to the text in which it is inserted.
Front: plain cross.
Interior left: male figure identified as Ato Amarä Behéral ( ?) with his rifle bearer; the text reads "how he put himself under the protection of Our lady Mary."
Interior right: Ascension with the figures of Adam and Eve "risen from their sleep."
Back: blank except for scribbles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The style of the drawing of the fourth bifolia differs markedly from that of the other three, and is probably by a different artist.
Unrelated to the text in which it is inserted.
Front: faint drawing of a figure.
Interior left: St. Michael.
Interior right: scribbles.
Back: blank except for faint scribbles.
